Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of COMET, A Cognitive RadiO Multimedia NEtwork Testbed for Multimedia Communication Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, building a Cognitive RadiO Multimedia NEtwork Testbed (COMET), investigates research challenges focused on QoE (Quality of Experience) requirements of multimedia applications, supporting new diverse approaches to QoE. The instrument will be used to develop cutting edge protocols and algorithms for the efficient use of limited wireless spectrum in a variety of multidisciplinary multimedia applications to address the challenging multidimensional scientific and engineering problems associated with the field. The protocols and algorithms will be applied to fundamental scientific questions in a wide range of wireless multimedia topics. The COMET platform will help develop methodology and techniques for efficient use of spectral resources and address critical issues related to energy, bandwidth, computing, and reliability for wireless multimedia applications. The work enables the verification and refinement of existing protocols and algorithms, and the development of new ones for different applications. The instrument directly services five projects:
- QoE-driven Cross-layer Design for CR Multimedia Networks,
- Cognitive Radio (CR) Infrastructure-based EV Micro-Grid for Future Power Grid Systems,
- Personalized Health Monitoring for Multimedia eHealth,
- Smart Autonomous Fault-Tolerant Environments (SAFE) of Cognitive Wireless Multimedia Sensor Networks, and
- Networked Distributed Source Coding for Multimedia Sensor Networks.

The instrument plays a crucial role in training the next generation of engineers and scientists. Students gain experience in various aspects of multimedia communication and wireless. Undergraduates are integrated into respective research programs, in harmony with the REU site program and college-level undergraduate research incentive program. Training is also offered to a broader body of students at the institution and beyond, and underrepresented students are sought. An undergraduate research program on CR multimedia network is established as well, while disseminating the novel principles and methods of multimedia communication developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has established a Cognitive RadiO Multimedia NEtwork Testbed (COMET) at the UMassD and addressed the needs in both research and education in the area of next-generation multimedia communications. The COMET platform has helped the verification and refinement of existing protocols and algorithms and development of new ones for the efficient use of limited wireless spectrum. It has also offered the education and training to both undergraduate and graduate students.

In this project, the components proposed for constructing the COMET testbed have been purchased, installed and tested. The physical platform mainly includes 60 USRP nodes, Video codec, Switches, WBX USRP daughterboard, SBX USRP daughterboard, and computer servers. The remote operation of COMET is enabled through protected internet connections and servers. We demonstrated the functionality and feasibility of the proposed testbed through several research projects that have been performed based on the COMET platform. Specifically, the COMET platform helps address research issues related to cognitive radio (CR)-based transmission of multimedia data. In addition, we have conducted research on communication interference, health monitoring for multimedia e-health applications, reliability of sensor networks and IoT systems in fault-tolerant environments, and cognitive radio infrastructure. We demonstrated potential use of software defined radios (SDRs) for diverse multimedia applications. For example, we designed a game user-oriented CR network for video transmission which takes the network user's QoE (Quality of Experience) requirements into the consideration for optimal network performance. Our theoretical analysis and numerical results show that, under the proposed CR network, both primary and secondary systems achieve better performance.

The COMET also provided opportunities in training the next generation of engineers and scientists. Both graduate and undergraduate students have been involved and gained experiences and skills in various aspects of multimedia communication and CR multimedia networks. Findings from this project were incorporated into a graduate course on Multimedia Communications, disseminating novel principles and methods of multimedia communication developed. Undergraduates are involved through a senior design project and multiple class projects in the course of Wireless Networks and Mobile Security. The platform has also been utilized in several graduate students' dissertations and thesis. Training is also offered to a broader body of students at the institution and beyond. The findings from this project has been disseminated via various public and academic venues such as conference and journal papers and a project website.
